opposingBeliefs: People won't work if they get free money
mainClaim: Universal Basic Income trials show recipients work similar hours while experiencing significant improvements in mental health, education, and entrepreneurship
evidence: Finland's 2-year UBI trial (â‚¬560/month to 2,000 unemployed) showed recipients worked 6 days more per year than control group while reporting 55% less stress and 46% less depression. Kenya's GiveDirectly study (largest UBI trial: 20,000+ people, $22/month for 12 years) found employment increased 4%, business creation up 12%, no reduction in work hours. Stockton, California pilot ($500/month, 125 recipients, 2019-2021) showed full-time employment increased from 28% to 40%, compared to 5% in control group. Recipients used money for: food (37%), utilities (23%), auto expenses (11%), NOT alcohol/tobacco (less than 1%). Y Combinator pilot in Kenya found recipients invested in education, started businesses, improved housing. Economic modeling by Roosevelt Institute shows $1,000/month UBI would grow US economy 12.56% over 8 years through increased spending.
supportingPoints: Removes welfare cliff that discourages work under current systems
Reduces stress allows job searching, training, education
Enables entrepreneurship by providing safety net for risk-taking
Multiple trials across countries show consistent results
Alaska Permanent Fund Dividend (40+ years) shows no employment reduction
limitations: Limited trial durations (most 1-3 years) may not reflect long-term behavior. Different results in developing vs developed nations. Funding mechanism unclear at scale. Inflation concerns if broadly implemented. Some trials had small sample sizes. Cultural factors affect outcomes.
counterCounterArguments: Funding via VAT, carbon tax, or automation tax is economically feasible
Alaska model demonstrates political viability across decades
Inflation concerns addressable through careful implementation

sourceMetadata.title: Modeling the Macroeconomic Effects of Universal Basic Income
sourceMetadata.methodology: Macroeconomic modeling combining data from 8 international UBI trials
